name: NPR
text:
Sen. Tim Scott says Senate Republicans are considering a proposal to increase police training to focus on de-escalation tactics â€” as well as setting up a commission to get a handle on concerns facing policing today.

name: NPR
text:
North Korea will cut off all communications with South Korea and treat it as an "enemy," according to North Korea's state media. 

The move comes just a month after the countries traded fire at their heavily patrolled border.
https://t.co/FWEc5XDOnz

name: NPR
text:
NEW: CrossFit CEO Greg Glassman has resigned. 

He had come in under fire in recent days for inflammatory comments he made about the Black Lives Matter movement.
https://t.co/HhHFxDFeZq

name: NPR
text:
Activists in Bristol, U.K., had spent years trying to remove the statue of slave trader Edward Colston, to no avail.

In the end, the statue's fate was not resolved by lawmakers in Bristol, but by a killing on a sidewalk in Minneapolis.  
https://t.co/OEWfA1T0jc

name: NPR
text:
After being laid off, Liz had to suddenly work out how to find health insurance coverage in the middle of a pandemic.

It wasn't easy: She had to call the county, talk to the insurance company, and navigate a difficult application. It took weeks to enroll.
https://t.co/z8wq1OPnu7

name: NPR
text: RT @NPRnie: "NPR has reviewed court documents of 51 individuals facing federal charges in connection with the unrest. As of Tuesday morning, none is alleged to have links to the antifa movement." Reporting by @relucasz  https://t.co/fEPu4PUUR4

name: NPR
text:
There are no alleged links to Antifa in any cases brought by the Justice Department over unrest so far, an NPR review of court records shows.
https://t.co/qt7E2eQv6o

name: NPR
text:
IBM will stop selling its facial recognition technology amid nationwide protests for racial justice and police reform.

The company cited fears that such technology could be used by police to violate "basic human rights and freedoms."  https://t.co/qK9Akdx3d9

text:

text:
Some of the country's most polluting industries have flooded state regulators with requests to ease environmental regulations â€” saying the pandemic interferes with their ability to comply.

name: NPR
text:
NPR spoke to several families about what's happened since visitors were banned from nursing homes in mid-March. All reported seeing shocking declines in their loved ones.

Advocates for residents say it's time to re-think the outright ban.
